title: Junius S. Mobley
text: Junius S. Mobley (died January 2, 1904), also known as June Mobley, was a politician in <a href="South%20Carolina">South Carolina</a>. He was considered an ultra-radical, and was one of South Carolina's 1868 <a href="Radical%20Republican">Radical Republican</a> members of the <a href="Legislature">Legislature</a>. He reportedly became a preacher after the <a href="Reconstruction%20era">Reconstruction era</a>. Mobley was a political leader during the Reconstruction era in South Carolina and was involved in the distribution of <a href="ammunition">ammunition</a> to <a href="Freedman">freedmen</a>. He was part of the Union Brotherhood that replaced the <a href="Union%20League">Union League</a> in 1872. Mobley was from <a href="Union%20County%2C%20South%20Carolina">Union County, South Carolina</a>. John Schreiner Reynolds wrote about Mobley and other <a href="African%20American">African American</a> legislators in 1905. He was not a fan of Mobley's, and described him as "<a href="mulatto">mulatto</a>" and said he gave incendiary speeches causing bloodshed for the "men of his own race". He also referred to Mobley as a "vicious and mouthy <a href="Negro">Negro</a>".
